channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Trump signs executive order to pause TikTok ban, provide immunity to tech firms
item.description: The order follows TikTok going dark for about 14 hours after the Supreme Court upheld a law prohibiting the service from operating in the U.S. unless it breaks away from its parent company in China.
item.content:encoded:
The order follows TikTok going dark for about 14 hours after the Supreme Court upheld a law prohibiting the service from operating in the U.S. unless it breaks away from its parent company in China.

(Image credit: Ashley Landis/AP)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: PHOTOS: What we saw on Inauguration Day
item.description: On the day of President Donald Trump's second inauguration, thousands of supporters gathered in Washington, D.C. Take a look at what our photographers captured.
item.content:encoded:
On the day of President Donald Trump's second inauguration, thousands of supporters gathered in Washington, D.C. Take a look at what our photographers captured.

(Image credit: Brian Munoz)
item.dc:creator: Brian Munoz

item.title: Trump offers long-promised pardons to some 1,500 January 6 rioters
item.description: On the campaign trail, Trump regularly featured the stories of Jan. 6 defendants he labeled "hostages" and "patriots."
item.content:encoded:
On the campaign trail, Trump regularly featured the stories of Jan. 6 defendants he labeled "hostages" and "patriots."

(Image credit: Samuel Corum)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: Trump revokes Biden's order for federal agencies to promote voter registration
item.description: President Trump has reversed an executive order by former President Joe Biden that calls for federal agencies to promote voter registration.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump has reversed an executive order by former President Joe Biden that calls for federal agencies to promote voter registration.

(Image credit: Sean Rayford)
item.dc:creator: Hansi Lo Wang

item.title: Trump is back and ready to change America
item.description:
Donald Trump returns to Washington newly empowered.

The Republican party has remade itself in his image. The Supreme Court has granted him sweeping immunity for his official actions. And, unlike last time, he narrowly won the popular vote.

And Trump is prepared to exercise his new power almost immediately. He's pledged to sign an unprecedented wave of executive actions – many of which will be challenged in court.

These actions include one making it U.S. policy to recognize only two biologically distinct sexes – male and female. And his administration would end birthright citizenship — a right explicitly protected by the Constitution.

President Donald Trump's executive actions could make fundamental changes to some of the foundations of American government.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org
item.content:encoded:
Donald Trump returns to Washington newly empowered.

The Republican party has remade itself in his image. The Supreme Court has granted him sweeping immunity for his official actions. And, unlike last time, he narrowly won the popular vote.

And Trump is prepared to exercise his new power almost immediately. He's pledged to sign an unprecedented wave of executive actions – many of which will be challenged in court.

These actions include one making it U.S. policy to recognize only two biologically distinct sexes – male and female. And his administration would end birthright citizenship — a right explicitly protected by the Constitution.

President Donald Trump's executive actions could make fundamental changes to some of the foundations of American government.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

(Image credit: MORRY GASH)

item.title: Trump seeks to end telework for federal workers
item.description: President Trump has signed an executive action ordering federal agencies to bring their workers back to the office full time. Roughly 1.1 million federal employees are telework-eligible.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump has signed an executive action ordering federal agencies to bring their workers back to the office full time. Roughly 1.1 million federal employees are telework-eligible.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hsu

item.title: What to know about Trump cryptocurrency meme coins
item.description: The meme coins yo-yoed in value as Trump took office. Here is what you should know about the coins and cryptocurrency's future under the Trump administration.
item.content:encoded:
The meme coins yo-yoed in value as Trump took office. Here is what you should know about the coins and cryptocurrency's future under the Trump administration.

(Image credit: Mark Humphrey)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: It's America's 'Manifest Destiny' to plant a flag on Mars, Trump says
item.description: Trump says Americans should look to the stars, by sending astronauts to Mars.
item.content:encoded:
Trump says Americans should look to the stars, by sending astronauts to Mars.

(Image credit: Kevin Lamarque)
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: Biden's FBI director expressed 'vehement' opposition to Peltier commutation
item.description: Indigenous activist Leonard Peltier was convicted of killing two FBI agents in the 1970s.
item.content:encoded:
Indigenous activist Leonard Peltier was convicted of killing two FBI agents in the 1970s.

(Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein)
item.dc:creator: Ashley Lopez

item.title: Migrants left in despair at the border as asylum system shuts down
item.description: The CBP One app has provided nearly 900,000 people with asylum appointments since January 2023, contributing to a drop in illegal border crossings.
item.content:encoded:
The CBP One app has provided nearly 900,000 people with asylum appointments since January 2023, contributing to a drop in illegal border crossings.

(Image credit: Herika Martinez)
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta
